ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: this was a fascinating study of non-homeric ancient poetry, and i guarantee it will contribute to your understanding of other texts. the linguistic notes will also prove helpful in grounding your greek grammar.

A good course to further practice your Greek-reading skills  the emphasis is on reading and understanding the text and some of the issues it presents. While Hesiod doesnt have the name recognition of Homer, he too has a great influence on classical literature. As a senior preparing for the Greek comprehensive, I found that once I knew Hesiod, I saw his influence everywhere. Since his poetry makes up the bulk of the course, Id definitely recommend this on that account  hes a good poet to know. Professor Bakker takes you through the text well and also teaches some historical linguistics, and the workload is entirely reasonable.
Definitely! Hesiod is incredibly interesting and the wisdom poetry is really accessible and fun!
The material is really interesting, and it is a surprisingly light workload. Professor Bakker is very knowledgeable.
Yes, if they enjoy ancient Greek poetry.
